conclusion: Analyze the image to understand the process of an ideal gas changing states from A to B and C.
The image depicts a pressure-volume (P/V) diagram for an ideal gas with processes from state A to B and then to state C.
The diagram shows isothermal, adiabatic, and constant volume processes with dashed lines indicating these processes.
State A is at a higher pressure than state B, and state C is at a lower pressure than state B.
The process from A to B is isothermal, meaning the temperature remains constant.
Given that the temperature in state A is $127^{0}C$, the temperature in state B is also $127^{0}C$.
The process from B to C is adiabatic, meaning there is no heat transfer and the temperature decreases.
Focus on the initial condition given for state A to determine the temperature in state B.
The temperature of the gas in state B is $127^{0}C$.
